ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was a great class. I particularly valued the opportunity, following one of our classes, to hear about Ona's work at CBI.
Excellent introduction to negotiation and collaboration skills. Would have been more helpful if the timing of the course were more evenly spaced out.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Several opportunities to practice the skills being taught
We learned a lot about meeting process and negotiation, and got to practice those skills. I think the negotiation sessions were really helpful.

I loved the mutual gains negotiation portion of the course, and all of the games we played and out-of-class negotiations we held were incredibly helpful. I also enjoyed the meeting facilitation section.

The exercises (both in-class and outside of class) were very practical and provided hands-on learning experiences which enabled us to really learn negotiation and mediation skills. They were also tons of fun!
Group projects.
Simulations and discussion.
The course was well-paced and well-organized.
Fantastic instructor, interesting material, good application of concepts.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Number and duration of classes; the classes were too few and each one was too long.
Assignments were longer than I expected for a one-credit course, though very helpful for thinking through different topics.

I wish we had had more time. I got so much out of the few meetings we had, and feel that if this were 2- or 3-credit course, it would be even more helpful. I didn't find the process design section as useful, but that's also because my interest doesn't lie in that area. Other than that, the only improvement I could suggest would be to distribute readings electronically before class and require students to read them so that they are more prepared to discuss the concepts.

It would have been better had the class fall on the same day/ time each week it ran, as it was very difficult to fit this course into my class schedule because the classes fell I think on 3 different days/ times.There was perhaps a few too many assignments considering the short length of the class and the fact that it was only 1 credit. I would suggest dropping 1 or 2 assignments, perhaps the journal reflection.It would be nice if the course didn't focus only on public consultation, but also focused on other types of meetings (ie. corporate meetings, non-profit meetings), and other types of negotiations other than ie. land disputes (salary negotiations, etc.). I recognize that this is likely because this is the area of expertise of the instructor, but it would be nice to bring in other types of negotiations/ meetings.
This would be an excellent full-semester course.
Scheduling
Could be presented in terms of broader applicability, not just from the lens of the specific kind of work done by the instructor. The international angle could have been presented earlier.
The international aspect was not very engaging or well setup, and it would be great to have a slightly longer course with even more opportunity for application and learning about concepts.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective
n/a
Could use closer scrutiny of readings assigned
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I will have great need for negotiating and collaborating with people from different backgrounds, I felt better about those meetings after these classes.

I have done a lot of activism and wanted formal training in meeting facilitation, since I have had to do a lot of that. I also think that conflict resolution and negotiations are useful in all areas of environmental work (and life really).
I think that negotiation/ conflict resolution are invaluable skills to have for any environmental professional.
I'm interested in doing work similar to Ona's at CBI.
Necessary skill for all env. professionals.
This is an incredibly useful skill in life and in the future. I may try to do more facilitation in all aspects of work.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: For a practical skills course on improving negotiation and learning tools for solving multiparty disagreements in the future.
I will have great need for negotiating and collaborating with people from different backgrounds.
See previous
I wanted to develop negotiation/ conflict resolution skills.
To build skills and get a sense of the facilitation/consensus-building professional landscape.
Interest in topic
Personal interest, usefulness as a skill.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes
Yes, they exceeded my expectation. This is a very useful, practical class.
Yes
Yes! This courseexceeded my expectations.
Yes
Yes.
Yes, mostly. A longer course would ground it better.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I like that the groups were different for each assignment and I learned a lot from my classmates through these exercises. It might even be better for the professor to assign groups to model the way these negotiations will go in real life--you won't always know the person you are negotiating or collaborating with.
They were great opportunities to practice the skills being taught and hang out with FESers.
The negotiation exercises were very helpful, and it was nice to meet different people.

The group exercises we did were the highlight of the course. The mutual gains negotiation we did toward the end was a blast and very, very helpful to understanding how a real negotiation like that might unfold.
Several of the assignments required us to get together with a group outside of class. We had a lot of fun with the exercises, and made these work sessions into fun events.
Group work was the best part. We had a lot of fun, and had the opportunity to learn from each other; particularly the multi-stakeholder negotiation role play.
Great learning tool.
The group work was necessary to simulate multi-party negotiations.
So great to work in a group-- this is really key in this sort of work, and the course attracted particularly wonderful people.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a great class to develop your skills in very real life situations.
Come prepared with questions so you can benefit maximally from the instructor.
it's really interesting and, I think, valuable for any student looking to go into environmental management.
Engage with the material and learn what you can.
Take this course! For the limited amount of work you have to put in, you will get a lot out of it.
I highly recommend this course, and think the skills you will learn are useful.
Consider that even a light PSC requires a time commitment!
Take it.
Take it!
